content: The "Secure America's Vote Act of 2005" aims to improve the fairness and accuracy of voter registration. The "Secure America's Vote Act of 2005" focuses on enhancing voter registration by emphasizing the citizenship requirement on voter registration forms and prohibiting the rejection of applications for errors correctable by the state. The "Secure America's Vote Act of 2005" prohibits the rejection of voter registration applications for correctable errors and prevents the incorrect removal of eligible voters from registration lists by requiring databases to meet accuracy standards. The "Secure America's Vote Act of 2005" prohibits the removal of voters from registration lists based on felony status or death unless the database meets accuracy standards set by the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology. The "Secure America's Vote Act of 2005" prohibits removing voters from registration lists based on felony status or death unless the database meets accuracy standards. The term 'applicable database' refers to the database used by the State to determine felony status or death for individuals on the voter list. A conforming amendment is made to Section 303(a)(2)(A) of the Act. The "Secure America's Vote Act of 2005" mandates accuracy standards for voter registration databases and requires public notice of individuals removed from the list before federal elections. The "Secure America's Vote Act of 2005" requires states to publicly announce the names removed from voter registration lists, along with the criteria for removal and the appeal process for reinstatement before federal elections. The "Secure America's Vote Act of 2005" mandates states to disclose names removed from voter lists, removal criteria, and reinstatement appeal process before federal elections. Amendments include changing references from "subtitle" to "Act" and specifying compliance exceptions for accuracy standards in voter removal databases. The "Secure America's Vote Act of 2005" requires states to disclose names removed from voter lists by January 1, 2006, including removal criteria and reinstatement appeal process. SEC. 3. UNIFORM STANDARD FOR TREATMENT OF PROVISIONAL BALLOTS CAST AT INCORRECT POLLING PLACES. Section 302(a)(4) of the Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to allow provisional ballots to be counted as votes in Federal elections if the individual is determined eligible to vote in that election at the polling place where the ballot was cast or at any other polling place for the same election for the same Federal office. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 allows provisional ballots to be counted as votes in Federal elections if the individual is determined eligible to vote at the polling place where the ballot was cast or at any other polling place for the same election for the same Federal office. In addition, State or local election officials must ensure that a list of registered voters and their polling places is available at each polling place for Federal elections. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 allows provisional ballots to be counted as votes in Federal elections if the individual is determined eligible to vote. SEC. 4. ADDITIONAL SECURITY REQUIREMENTS FOR VOTING SYSTEMS. Section 301(a) of the Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to include new paragraphs regarding security standards for voting systems used in federal elections. No voting system can be used in a federal election unless the manufacturer, software provider, and chief State election official meet specific requirements. The system used in a State must have all custodians of the election software digitally sign the software according to NIST standards. The chief State election official is responsible for ensuring this and providing information to the Commission, which must be made public on the official website. The manufacturer of the election system and software must provide updated information on individuals involved in writing the software, including any felony convictions or crimes related to election fraud. They are also required to provide source code, object code, and executable representation to the Commission and chief State election official. The manufacturer of the election system and software must meet standards to prevent conflicts of interest and notify officials of any code alterations. The text discusses the prohibition of wireless communication devices in voting systems and the restriction on connecting voting system components to the internet. The text prohibits connecting any voting system component to the internet. SEC. 5. PUBLICATION OF STATE ELECTION LAWS. Requiring States to make election laws available to the public by publishing all state laws, regulations, procedures, and practices relating to Federal elections on January 1 of each election year and maintaining them on the internet. States must post all election-related material on the chief State election official's public website and update it within 24 hours of any revisions. Amendments to the Act specify the details of this requirement. SEC. 6. CRIMINAL PENALTIES FOR VOTER SUPPRESSION. Section 905 of the Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to include a new subsection (c) addressing voter suppression. It is unlawful to falsely assert someone's eligibility to vote or provide false information about voting. Violators will be fined according to title 18, United States Code. Violators of voter suppression laws may be fined or imprisoned for up to 1 year under title 18, United States Code. Establishment of best practices for treatment of absentee ballots of absent uniformed services voters and overseas voters by the Election Assistance Commission in cooperation with relevant government agencies. Definitions of "absent uniformed services voter" and "overseas voter" provided. Simultaneous transmission of budget requests of Election Assistance Commission to President and Congress. The Help America Vote Act of 2002 is amended to include a new section requiring the Election Assistance Commission to submit budget requests to both the President and Congress. These amendments will apply to federal elections starting in 2006.
